Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Avoiding Secondary Disasters: Wastewater Treatment Design and (Re)construction during Large-Scale Disaster Response

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1539775
Gough

The aftermath of Hurricane Katrina in the Gulf Coast demonstrated the potential for severe environmental impacts to area waterways caused by displaced populations overwhelming wastewater treatment facilities in host communities. The call for scholarly literature on rapid response for wastewater treatment recovery after disasters has gone largely unanswered. This proposal addresses a window of opportunity for obtaining data on the wastewater treatment response in a refugee camp in the Azraq region of the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan, where the population is expected to swell from 10,000 to over 100,000 during the next year.

A moving-bed biofilm reactor was installed for wastewater treatment at this camp in December 2014. The camp population will grow substantially while the moving-bed biofilm reactors will be brought on-line. Study of this unprecedented period of scale-up will fill a data void regarding both the function of moving-bed biofilm reactor, which are un-tested for extreme high loading conditions, and the response of these extreme conditions on operator decision making. During disaster response, such as this response to displaced persons, infrastructure decisions must be made rapidly and often lead to misinformed decisions. Several organizations have developed guidance for effective (re)construction (i.e. adjusts to the original design after initial construction) by revisiting projects after completion. Those efforts are incremental mainly focused on descriptive solutions, and have rarely considered the wastewater treatment infrastructure. In fact, pit toilets and latrines are among the most common recommendations for displaced populations when local (host) community wastewater facilities cannot accommodate the extra flow. However, lack of treatment places already vulnerable populations at risk of waterborne diseases and places the local area at risk of long-term environmental impacts. Thus, Azraq is a unique study situation in which decisions have been made to use modern wastewater treatment technologies in a situation where many of the treatment system design parameters were unknown so that informed and organized (re)construction decisions will be critical to operational success. This project will establish a framework for coordinated comparison of the decision making framework on wastewater treatment performance under real-time, high-stress operations. This project combines advancements in two disciplines and will examine the complex relationship between people driven actions through a decision making process and the impact on a wastewater treatment system measured by its environmental qualities. Understanding delivery of wastewater treatment at the Azraq refugee camp will establish a framework against which research into other disaster response situations can be compared. This project will be of broad interest, as the Middle East conflicts are gaining more media coverage with increased US involvement, and will help educate the general public on the importance of wastewater treatment in times of crisis. Collaboration between University of Washington and the Jordan University for Science and Technology will increase the international collaboration of the investigators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When a disaster happens that causes large numbers of people to move, treatment of wastewater is critical to ensure protection of human health and the environment. For example, following Hurricane Katrina in the Gulf Coast, severe environmental impacts to waterways occurred when displaced people overwhelmed wastewater treatment facilities in host communities. While large scale weather-related natural disasters are predicted to increase in frequency and veracity, the call for scholarly literature on rapid response for wastewater treatment recovery after disasters has gone largely unanswered. In part, this is because these events are hard to predict and hard to access - making data collection difficult.

There is an unprecedented displacement of people from Syria right now – with the UN estimating that more people are displaced now than after WWII. World-wide, leaders must decide if their countries and communities can host these huge numbers of refugees. A part of this is estimating impacts on host communities, including environmental impacts such as from wastewater. This project addressed a limited window of opportunity for obtaining data on the wastewater treatment efforts in a refugee camp in the Azraq region of the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan. The goal of this 1.5 year study was to document “lessons learned” by collecting chemical and biological data from the moving bed biofilm reactor (MBBR) treatment plant at 4 time points and by recording observations and experiences of wastewater treatment engineers, operators and technicians using interviews. This data will provide future disaster response teams with improved information when they make rapid decisions about how to manage wastewater for displaced persons.

Initial design and operation of the Azraq wastewater treatment plant had to be conducted without the benefit of documented operational parameters and guidelines. Project testing showed that the wastewater from the camp was 2 times more concentrated than “high strength” municipal wastewater, and had 10 times the ammonia concentrations – both of which were outside the range of operational design documents for MBBR. Due to delayed discharge permits, the plant functioned with re-circulation for an extended period of time – this disrupted biologic growth and treatment efficiency. Additionally, changes to reactor configuration and switching reactors from aerobic to anoxic (in an attempt to treat the high ammonia concentrations) caused shifts in the microbial populations – which were observed to occur faster in the free-living populations than on the fixed biofilms. This suggested that when using technology with biofilms, longer times might be needed for reactor’s to respond to operational changes. Response of the microbial community to encourage biological removal of ammonia, the bacterial populations responsible for this activity were not observed, suggesting that either the conditions were not favorable (e.g. organic concentrations were too high) or that insufficient time was given for this slow-growing community to develop. In future, this might be compensated by seeding with a sludge known to contain ammonia degrading activities (such as from another treatment plant).

The teams operating the treatment plant reported that their professional experience was not always applicable to the project conditions, even though they all had previously worked in wastewater treatment or emergency response. For example, those that were familiar with the technology did not have previous experience from emergency response or wastewater treatment in extreme locations and conversely, those who were experts in crisis management or wastewater treatment in Jordan had not previously worked with MBBR technology. The lack of shared understanding of the technology and the project context hindered project performance and operational decision making, but became a smaller issue over time as all team members gained new skills and knowledge, started to understand the capabilities and limitations of the MBBR process, and learned to locate technical expertise within the group. As a result, decision processes became faster and simpler over time. 

Broader Impacts of the Project:

This project drew critical attention to the importance of wastewater treatment in times of crisis. As a first inter-disciplinary study of wastewater treatment operations – combining expertise in construction management and advanced biologic treatment – this study paves the way for enhanced understanding of how decision making influence biological treatment, both in settings such as the treatment operations at Azraq, during emergency response, and more generally during any wastewater treatment response event.

The project helped advance the training of two graduate students, including a female graduate student. The project also helped raise international visibility of female scientists; both US investigators and the primary international collaborators were female. One of the US investigators was an NSF beginning investigator. Collaboration between University of Washington (UW) and the Jordan University for Science and Technology (JUST) increased the international reputation of the investigators. The work has been shared at 3 national conferences. One manuscript is under revision, and two more are in preparation.
